Replies.Reply: 'Saving America From Itself.' What the fuck is this?
What time's your kid go off to school?
How about I come over and visit you later?
Come on. I mean it. I'm trying to change.
Hey, Simon, you a registered voter?
Excuse me, miss, are you a registered voter?
Well, I'd like to give you some information about Congressman Owen Feer. This man is gunna make a big difference in the lives of every American in the years to come...
What time's your mother get off work?
Fay, are you a registered voter?
I gotta regular job now and everything.
He's gunna be the next president of the United States of America, Fay.
He's a decent man. He takes complicated issues and totally simplifies them. And I appreciate that.
No. You know what the problem is with this country, Fay? Me. I'm the problem. We live in a culture of poverty and crime, where the work ethic is undermined and male responsibility is made irrelevant.
She gives you any trouble, Fay, you just let me know.
Jesus Christ, Simon, you're letting yourself go to hell! You read that flyer I gave you?
Simon, wake up and smell the coffee, huh! It's up to guys like you and me to help create a better tomorrow!
Why would I steal a computer from the campaign office?
Listen, Henry, I wanna remind you to vote this Thursday.
It's every American's right. A blessing. Yet another opportunity to save America from itself.

What's the fucking use. You make sacrifices. You try to be a decent human being. Try to contribute something meaningful to society. And what happens? They lose to a bunch of cultural elite liberal fuck-ups. I don't give a shit anymore. People deserve what they get.
Yeah, who the hell do you think you are, anyway?
Where the hell have you been?
Shit, Mom, we gotta get him to a hospital!
Fine! You do it, Simon! I don't care!
Mom! Simon's got a broken rib, his shoulder's dislocated or something, and he won't let me disinfect the gash in his head!
So, do you have, like, you know, a girlfriend, Henry?
I look young for my age, don't I?
How old do you think I am?
But how... I mean, do I look more like twenty, or... you know, thirty?
Listen, you geek, after a couple of drinks plenty of people mistake me for eighteen!
Well, leave 'em there on the counter, then.
Yeah! Get outta here, you freak!
Don't you dare talk that way to me! And keep your hands off my brother. Pearl, what are you doing here?
You and Vicky get back together?
I saw this retard on TV this morning.
Keep dreamin' Warren. The guy's a Nazi.
Come on, Pearl, let's go play at my house.
What do you mean, you quit?
I am not gettin' a job!
Mom can't be left alone with no one to keep an eye on her.
What happened to her, Simon? How did she get this way? Will it happen to me too? Huh? Why are we so fucked up?
computer's got a program especially for it. I bought some special stationery too. It's scented. Look.
Simon, Mom's right about you. A poem's supposed to be a small, delicate kinda thing. Kinda feminine. Gentle. Look at this. You've made a fuckin' telephone book.
Gnoc, gimme a value pack of Kleenex, will ya?
No, I'm not alright! Your poem brought my period on a week and half early! So just shut up. Everybody just shut up!
Yeah, but when were you in Paris?
So what about this friend of yours, Hot Shot? The publisher.
Yeah. Angus James. How about sending this poem to him?
When's it gunna be done, Simon?
Well, you oughta be home writing instead of hanging out over here with all your groupies.
Pardon me, swivel-hips. Is that your PowerBook?
You can't talk to him for, you know, too long or anything, 'cause he's gotta, you know... he writes all day. That's all he does. Can you believe that?
Simon, this is Edna. She's from the newspaper.
Mom, this is Edna. Edna, Mom.
Simon, wake up! The guy's in a dream world!
If he's such a great big fat genius, why doesn't he write books? Like you do.
Yeah, I bet. It's probably disgusting.
Yeah, well, what ever. Listen, Simon, forget Henry. Go straight up to this Angus James character yourself and make him read your poem.
I'm gunna apply for a job at the one-
Hey, Henry, you in there? Gimme a cigarette.
I don't wanna talk about it, Henry!
I don't know if he would want us to do that.
God, Simon, I mean, like, you're a total fucking rock star.
Listen, you degenerate, I've had about enough of this!
Henry, don't come home tonight! I'm warning you! Don't come home at all! Ever!
We were married seven years ago.
I don't know, honey. Leave me alone a minute, I gotta think.
Yes, Ned, he is. He's in big trouble. Now just be quiet for two minutes.
Sure you can, honey. You can be anything you want.
I don't know why you cooked! I don't know why you bother!
Did you throw up all over some girl?
They were throwing bottles at the house.
She's got some ex-con in there she met at the bar. Tattoos all over himself and a big red bloated nose.
What's the use? She might as well get it while she can. She's not always gunna have the ass she has now, you know. That's just how life is.
This kinda thing has happened before.
Fay, just take him to the hospital, will ya!
Simon Grim, you go to the hospital with Fay right now, do hear me!
What are you doing there, Simon?
We all thought he was retarded.
And that's when all the trouble really started.
Yes, it was nice. But it was unremarkable.
Where you gotta go to get a six-pack of beer around here?
Centuries ago it had an 'e' at the end.
I go where I will and I do what I must.
That's why I'm in trouble. I'm sort've what you might call... 'in exile'.
An honest man is always in trouble, Simon. Remember that.
Well... I'll take your word for that.
...this. Keep them with you at all times. You ever feel like you got something to say and you can't get it out, stop and write it down. OK?
This? This is my life's work. My memoirs. My 'Confession'.
But why brag? The details of my exploits are only a pretext for a far more expansive consideration of general truths.

What is this? It's a philosophy. A poetics. A politics, if you will. A literature of protest. A novel of ideas. A pornographic magazine of truly comic-book proportions. It is, in the end, whatever the hell I want it to be. And when I'm through with it, it's gunna blow a hole this wide straight through the world's own idea of itself!
Come on, let's go break their arms!

Once. I forget where I was. Central America maybe. Somewhere hot. Stupid job. Bad pay. Dangerous location and water so foul the natives wouldn't even piss in it. This crowd of drunken motherfuckers hired by the local drug cartel shows up at my hotel room and threatens to tear me limb from limb. And I say, listen, hombres, OK, you've got me outnumbered four to one and you're gunna kill me here tonight and not a soul in this dimly lit world is ever gunna notice I'm gone. Fine. But one of you... one of you... one of you is gunna have his eye torn out. Period. Silence. I repeat myself. One of you poor, underpaid jerks is gunna have an eye ripped out of its socket. I promise. It's a small thing, perhaps, all things considered. But I will succeed. Because it's the only thing I have left to do in this world. So why don't you just take a good look at one another one last time and think it over for a few minutes more.
They sober up a little, look at their shoes in confusion, then step out into the hall to talk among themselves.
Well, here I am, still, after all.
Good morning, Simon! Glorious day, huh? Here, have a donut. Can you lend me twenty dollars?
Thanks. Where's the library in the scruffy little burgh?
Excellent! I'm polishing up the final chapters of my 'Confession' and I need a reasonably well-stocked reference section.
Simon! Who did this to you?
Of course I'm sure. I corrected the spelling myself.
Yeah, well, you know -- that's what poetry does.
What the hell were you trying to do when you wrote this thing?
Well, you know you wrote it in a kind of iambic pentameter.

Look, in my opinion, this is pretty powerful stuff. Though your spelling is Neanderthal, and your reasoning a little naive, your instincts are profound. But the whole thing needs to be given a more cohesive shape. It can be expanded. Followed through. Unified.
You see what I'm getting at?
Are you willing to commit yourself to this? To really work on it? To give it its due? In the face of adversity and discouragement? To rise to the challenge you yourself have set?
And don't gimme that wonderstruck 'I'm-only-a-humble-garbage-man' bullshit, either.
Yes. Now shut up and lie back.
It's blood. From your head. Lie back. Shove that in your mouth and hold on to something.
There's no accounting for taste, is there, Mr Deng?
See, Simon, there are three kinds of there. There's 'There'. T-H-E-R-E. There are the donuts. Then there's T-

And look, if you're gunna read Wordsworth you've gotta get a more up-to-date edition. This odoriferous tome you're so attached to doesn't even have all fourteen books of the Prelude. And you need notes. Commentary. I'll go to the library and find you the best edition they have.
You need time to write, Simon. To study. To reflect.

We all have to make sacrifices. A vocation like ours, Simon, is not a nine to five thing. You can't put a fence around a man's soul. We think and feel where and when we can think and feel. We are the servants of our muse and we toil where she commands.
Out there. You know, into the world. Where ever.
No. I found it in a fortune cookie.
No. Not yet. Soon. We'll see.

Well, you know, Simon, a piece of work like this, it's... A vocation like ours... You can't put a fence around a man's soul. What I'm trying to achieve, it's... Well, it takes a lifetime really. It's a life's work.
But soon. Don't worry. I'd appreciate your feedback. I gotta go. See ya.
I've got these books for Simon.

Listen. I know a man. He's a big shot in the publishing business. Angus James. Smart, adventurous and tons of integrity. When this thing is ready, I'll recommend he reads it. He'll respect my opinion.
Why do they torment me like this? Why? They're like a bunch of fucking mosquitoes!
They want to suffocate me, Simon! They wanna extinguish me like a flame!
They're afraid, that's why! They're afraid of what I might do! What I might say! Think! They're afraid of my ideas!
You and I are alike in this way, Simon.

We're outsiders. We think and feel too much and too deeply. And the world can't handle that. Our mere existence is a threat to its illusion of security. Sure, they'll name a wing of a new library after us when we're dead! But now... Now, when we're alive... Now, they wanna burn us at the stake!
For example, I made love to your mother about half an hour ago and now I'm beginning to think that maybe it wasn't such a good idea.
I mean to say, I think Fay may be jealous.
A poet has got to be able to think about anything.
Of course you are! A great poet! But you need experience. You need to do something to be ashamed of every once in a while, for cryin' out loud.
Come on! Let's go out! There's a den of iniquity right across the street! You got any money?
Come on. I got ya some coffee.
It's a computer. You write on it.
I stole it. Now listen. Remember how yesterday we discussed the relative desirability of cadence in relation to the readability of...
Simon, I can't work under these conditions.
Keep a look out. Tell me when he's gone.
He wants to help me! He wants to be my friend.
So, you're an honest man. Why beat yourself up about it?

Because vocation is the difference. Only someone who really cares doubts. Listen, father, as I was about to tell my friend Simon here, I am, without doubt, the biggest sinner within a hundred miles of this parish. But still, I've gotta stay up late at night to outdo the unending parade of mundane little atrocities I see committed every day right out in the open spaces of this loud and sunlit culture we call home.

I like to think so. But the fact is I appreciate depravity. Nevertheless, I insist your vocation makes a difference, because to hold out anything other than a spiritual yardstick to reality is to be jerking off grandly into the abyss. Listen, have you got any money? Let's go have a drink.
Worse than bad! Monstrous! But I love that about them.
Simon! What are you doing here?
Simon, just shut the fuck up!
OK. Look, do me a favor. You got a library card?

Milton. Seventeenth century. English. You see, Simon, it's important my 'Confession' dig up the past, comb previous evidence and help chart the historic -- even the aesthetic -- inevitability of my ideas. And...
This place is crawling with chicks, Simon. Wander around. Leer a little. Cop a feel. Impose yourself on 'em. See what happens.
Bullshit! You've got a rough hewn charm that sets 'em on edge. Now, listen, I gotta go.
What happened to this assistant librarian position you were supposed to set me up with?
So my word is not enough. My promise worthless. The fact I've served my time nothing but the emblem of my continuing guilt.
I was caught. Yes, I was caught...

It was a pathetic little conspiracy. A transparently desperate attempt to discredit me and my ideas; to label me a mere pedophile. As if I'd be ashamed of such a thing. As if Socrates himself hadn't been taken out of circulation for corrupting the youth of Athens!

Seven years. Seven years for one afternoon of blissful transgression. But what of it? Who cares? Prison's not so bad; particularly if one's a sex offender, free from the popular and conventional horror of sodomy.
I put them to good use. I began my major work. My opus.
Believe me, Simon, this incident with the girl, prison... It pales to insignificance in the wider context of my career.
Nothing in comparison to the day my 'Confession' is unleashed.

What an orgy we'll have then, huh? What shouts of outrage from the offended populace, from the sanctimonious purveyors of culture and quality, the righteous defenders of what ever inane and haphazard notion of progress then in vogue. They'll be beside themselves with fiercely reasoned critical analysis. Apoplectic with indignation!
Yes, like a mirror which reflects only the inside of the person before it, my 'Confession' will lovingly render humanity's common monstrosity in all of its lurid wide screen glory.
Why should I blush or feel shame before the common lot of humanity, anyway, for a few banal and, again I admit, inelegant transgressions?
After all, really, I'm doing civilization a favor.

The greats all say the same thing: little. And what little there is to be said is immense. Or, in other words, follow your own genius to where it leads without regard for the apparent needs of the world at large, which, in fact, has no needs as such, but, rather, moments of exhaustion in which it is incapable of prejudice.
We can only hope to collide with these moments of unselfconsciousness. This divine fatigue... this...
That's beside the point. But did they listen to me? Of course not!
For is this not the best of all possible worlds? Are not the evils of this world necessary components of a cosmos that could not exist without them?
Go ahead. But never let yourself be flattered.
The thing to do is to send parts of it to different magazines and literary journals first. That kinda thing. You know. Substantiate it.
Filth, child. A preoccupation with excrement. Why?
About taste. You can't argue about taste. God, Simon.
What do you mean you don't know why you bother? You bother because you know the poem is excellent!

Can you sit there, look me straight in the eye, and tell me you don't think this poem is great? That it is not at once a work of great lyrical beauty and ethical depth? That it is not a genuine, highly individual, and profound meditation on the miracle of existence?
So, you see, you have no choice!
That might not be as easy as it seems.
Well, it's been a long time. My name might not carry as much weight as it once did with Angus.
We were close at one time.
Look, Simon, opinions come and go.
To be honest; my ideas, my writing, they haven't always been received well or even calmly. They're upsetting. I'm a controversial man.
You see, what I'm doing is too radical. Too uncompromising. It'll take time for people to see its value. It's ahead of its time, perhaps, or maybe just...
A recommendation from me might do you as much harm as it does good.
Because certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.
In the infinite amplitude of his love, God wants to create the largest number of best elements that can exist together in one cosmos... OK.

In an instantaneous calculation made in eternity, God computes the best possible world and creates it. Fine. This 'decision' by God is uncontingent and eternal rather than temporally or ontologically sequential.
O-N-T... Don't you have some kinda spell-check on that thing?
It is impossible for every perfect good to be compatible with every other perfect good. The intense beauty of the mountain must be set off by the fertility of the plain, so to speak.
The good of freewill must entail real choices for sin.
Listen, Amy, back off. I'm on parole.
Hey! I don't look at you.
I look at a lot of people that way.
No, as a matter of fact, I think you're a real bright kid and I like that about you.
I like it so much I've got half a mind to do perverse things to you. Right here. Right now. Things you might just learn to like.
I'm just looking at the pictures.
I learn so much from these magazines, Mr Deng. I refuse to discriminate between modes of knowing.
This place is losing all its charm, Mr Deng.
It's just a fad, Mr Deng. These kids today, they're just slaves to fashion.
Come on, Mr Deng! How much do I owe you?
That can't be right! And so what? My credit's good.
Hey, Warren, you gotta couple of bucks I can borrow?
Ah, yes, of course. When noble minds shrink from the task of leadership scoundrels will rush in to fill the void.
So I was a janitor! So what?

Well, I mean, we weren't like bosom buddies or anything. But we used to talk sometimes. In the elevator. In the morning. He said he liked my ideas. Being a janitor's a good job if you're a writer. Especially the night shift; all that time to think and develop my ideas.
Well, what the hell does he know? He wouldn't know a vital piece of literary art if it came up and bit him in the leg. To hell with him! He's not the only publisher in the world!
It's true. A prophet is seldom heeded in his own land. Remember that.
Hey, Warren, I found Pearl wandering around by the garbage dump.
Oh. Well, you know. Somebody's gotta lose.
I found Pearl wandering around with no shoes on her feet.
A double espresso and a jelly donut, Gnoc.
No, but it's OK. Simon's gunna try to get me a job on the garbage truck.
'Her figure makes me violent. I want to somehow break her. But tenderly. How is this possible? Ask Henry.'  Henry thinks this over, gulps back some espresso and nods his approval. Then...
Is all this true about the Internet? About how you can get pornography on it?
Gnoc, gimme one of these double espressos to go, will ya?
You gotta get outta the house, Fay. You can't blame yourself for not being here. You did all you could for her.
You got the Internet on that contraption?
Look Fay, about, you know, between us -- what happened...
Type a part of Simon's poem onto the Internet.
Come on, Fay. It's a great idea.
Sure he would. Just the first ten verses.
He'll thank you for it later.
Gimme another one of those tall double espressos, Mr Deng.
There's this fascinating story about a famous rock band and how they tied a friend of theirs to a bed in their hotel room and inserted a live fish into her vagina.
They say she had numerous orgasms.
I mean, it wasn't the entire fish, it was just, you know, the nose. The nose of the fish.
You ever wonder what it would be like to have sex with an animal, Mr Deng?
I mean, some dogs are almost as big as people and often more attractive.
Simon, I don't feel so good.
I feel all kinda clammy. And damp.
How much you think I can get for this?
I, Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.
And do promise before God and these witnesses...
To be your loving and faithful husband.
For as long as we both shall live.

I've let myself down, Simon! I've let myself be caught in the bloody maw of banal necessity! How did I get here? How did this happen to me? I'm going to be somebody's father! I need time to think. To write. Time to finish my 'Confession'! I can't work for a living! It's impossible! I tried once. My genius will be wasted trying to make ends meet!
This is how great men topple, Simon. Their hearts are in the right place too much of the time! They get sidetracked! Distracted. Oh! How could I have been so careless!
No. Not now. It's not done. I'm all washed up. I'm finished!
You'd do that? You'd do that for me?
Do you realize what you're saying?
Ah. I see. Well, what now?
I mean, after all, there are things I can do to make it more accessible.

I can soften up some of the language and make it read easier. Take out some of the more intratextual references and popularize the underlying Sturm und Drang, so to speak. I can change its mode. Make it more of a conventional novel instead.
Oh, Simon, don't be such a purist! I appreciate your protectiveness, but the integrity of the work gives it a durability that can sustain such things.
What are you saying; that it doesn't merit revision?
Well, did you tell him what you think?
Yes, it does. You've got to use your influence with him.
You can refuse to let him publish your poem.
I... I don't know. Honesty, perhaps.
I would have respected your opinion.
Oh how perfectly enormous of you, Simon.
Is that such a priority? Is that some sort of measure of a man's worth? To drag what's best in him out into the street so every average slob with some pretense to taste can poke it with a stick?

You must be pretty impressed with yourself, huh? The all too obviously talented new man, the important new voice, the early clue to a new direction, or whatever, etc., etc., etc! A popular new trend conveniently packaged for the distracted young herd! You want to be liked more than you know, Simon Grim! You'd be nowhere without me and you know it.
I saw you for what you were in the beginning, Simon. I hold no grudge and I'm certain you will, in time, leave some serious and small dent in this world.

The world is full of shit. It's true. And you have to walk through it. That's your part. I'm sorry. But you're no good at it. Perhaps I'm not. Perhaps I wasn't made to walk through shit. Go on now. Leave. Do what you're good at. Go.
So what did you learn at school today, Ned? Anything?
See. That'll teach ya. Here, sip this.
God, they must be hard up for geniuses to pin medals on because, listen, I gotta tell you, when I first met this guy he didn't even know what an iambic pentameter was.
Keep a lid on it, Bill, you're outta your league.
He's a great American poet, you dumb fuck!
Come over here and say that and I'll cripple ya in three different ways, you boozed-up Philistine!
What did I tell you! It was just a fad. I told you that! I told everyone!
Yeah yeah yeah. So what? A Nobel Prize. Anybody can get one of them these days. That's the problem, with this world, Mr Deng... Nobody's got any standards anymore. You seen Fay?
I can't sleep in there with that racket!
What are you doing here, Pearl?
That was a long time ago.
You oughta get outta here, Pearl.
Vicky! Vicky, it's Henry from across the street! Vicky!
Look, Simon, the world's a scary place. I admit it. But it's not my fault. I swear!
Don't be. You had things to do.
Take care of your mom and don't start trouble you can't finish.
Uhm. Look, ah... I'm the editor of the high school newspaper now and...
One of the editors, and we...
I... wanted to know if we could print your poem in this month's issue.
That's what the Board of Education called Simon's poem, yesterday; scatological.
You feel the same way. I can tell. I can see it when you look at me.
Yes you do. In the street. In the parking lot yesterday. That night on the highway.
What kind of... Well, I mean... What kind of... perverse things would you do to me?
They're even talking about it on the TV news.
There's a guy from the radio station over at World of Donuts and a story in the newspaper about some kids burning down a school near Boston!
Stay the hell out of my store, you good-for-nothing punks!
Look at this! What's going on here? Simon, get up off the floor! Is this beer paid for?
You should take him home. He smells like a toilet.
But she has never spoken in her life.
And you can't smoke in here anymore.
Business is good. The kids, they hang out all day and drink coffee, talk about art and read poetry.
Henry, you need to do something with your life. Get a job, or something.
That coffee is free. Just take it and get out of here.
We gotta have rock 'n' roll shows these days, Henry. The poetry readings just don't pay the bills no more.
Did you hear about Simon? It was on the news today.
You better sleep in my office tonight, Henry. She was very angry. You've gotta let her cool off.
How do you know my name?
People. I mean. They think. You know. Because.
You want me to tell her to be quiet?
Down the highway about a mile and a half and then make a left.
I thought. Um. I was. I wanted to. Maybe.
One of you is gunna lose an eye.
One of you is gunna lose an eye!
You can set me on fire. But one of you is gunna have an eye torn out of your head. I promise.
I was gunna tear out their eyes. I knew I could do it.
I told them. Like you said. I told them. And I knew I could do it.
Thank you, but that's OK. I'll stop there on my way back from work. Well, yes, maybe not today, but, you know, tomorrow, probably.
I guess it means it's not her fault.
A man was here today looking for you.
I don't know. He drove by the house a few times.
What do they want from you?
I don't want to think about this.
Henry, what's going on? Who is that guy? What's he want?
There are things I want to do.
Now you have to go out and get a job!
If you treat Mom like a sick person, she's gunna stay like... you know, a sick person.
I can see with my own eyes.
Well, who's been keeping an eye on her while you've been out getting fucked by every OTB winner in town?
Henry sighs and sits back down.
He told me to tell you that if you don't call him they're gunna put you back in jail.
He was talking to Mr Deng too, and, well, you know, I was thinking...
Why is it this beautiful girl makes me sad? Does she know how beautiful she is? Do people tell her? Does she ever feel stupid?
Why don't I smile when she looks at me? I look away. Ashamed of myself.
Her figure makes me violent. I want to somehow break her. But tenderly. How is this possible? Ask Henry.

Why do I do this to myself? And why do I reduce you to only one possibility? These are not even questions anymore. I know the answers myself. This isn't a page of notes. It's a letter. A letter to you. A desperate act. You are a miracle to me. I can't breathe.
Can you type my poem into that thing?
Yes, but... do you think Henry is...

Dear Mr Grim, we here at the magazine consider ourselves and the publication open-minded and cutting edge and have consistently printed the work of the most brilliant and farseeing young talent of the day. Every week we are forced to return writing which we can not for one reason or another publish and include a brief but polite refusal. But this tract you've sent us demands a response as violent as the effect your words have had upon us. Drop dead. Keep your day job. Sincerely, The Editors.
The other twenty-five are almost as bad. I don't know why I bother.
Can you recommend it to your friend, the publisher?
Henry? Can you recommend the poem to him?
I mean, I think it's finished and, for better or worse, it is book length.
You said he respected your opinion.
Henry, why can't I read the 'Confession'?
He's afraid that his reputation will prevent people from giving my work an honest chance.
He's kinda like in exile. Marginalized on account of his ideas.
He has. He's written a book. It's almost completed. He's been working on it for years. It's just not published.
It's a quite serious and difficult piece of work, apparently.
No. Not yet. Soon. Certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of its character.
That was nice what you were playing.
I'm here to see Mr. Angus James.
I'm not a plumber. Or a messenger. I was once a garbage man. But now I'm a poet.
Why can't I see him now?
I wouldn't want to waste your time.
A friend of mine spoke of you. He said you had a lot of integrity.
But Angus James said he didn't even know you!
I think it's a gasket. A fitting from off of that old refrigerator over there.
You've got to tell him, Fay.
How many of these did you have?
What made you change your mind?
A hundred thousand in cash up front.
Henry, please, let me read the 'Confession'.
Angus James is convinced my poem is going to make him incredibly wealthy. He'll read your book and seriously consider publishing it. If I ask him to. I'm certain.
Or I won't let him publish my poem.
That's what you said about my poem.
But just exactly what is the nature of your faith in my writing?
He taught me everything I know.
How about if my advance is only a hundred thousand?
Listen, Henry, Angus James didn't like your 'Confession'.
I'm saying... Angus James didn't like it.
I gave it to him to read and he hated it. What more can I do?
That was before I read your book.
Look, Henry, what did you expect?
Look, if I had told you, when at first I read it, that I thought it was no good, what would you have done?
And insisted that there's no accounting for taste.
I don't know. I didn't bring it to Angus because I thought it was good. I brought it to Angus because you're my friend.

Look, Henry, I did it! I wrote. I wrote poetry because you told me to! I worked! I worked while you sat back and comfortably dismissed the outside world as too shallow, stupid and mean to appreciate your ideas.
The world is full of shit.
Hey, Warren, are you a registered voter?
It's everything you need to know about the upcoming elections and congressman Owen Feer and all the really good things he wants to do for our country.
He wants to win back this country for us Americans, Warren, and restore some kind of cultural-moral standard to our way of life.
Well, I don't know, Warren. I mean...
How dare you put something like this up where anyone can see it!
It's pornography! The product of a diseased mind! You oughta be ashamed of yourself, Mr Deng!
It's disgusting! There oughta be a law or something!
I'm not saying you did, I'm just saying one was and since you do have this criminal background...
Don't you even come near me!
He's a good man, Henry. Nobody's perfect.
What do you think you're doing, you idiot!
So what? It ain't so great.
So, do you believe in God?
Simon, can I have your autograph?
The violence of the imagery reminds me of early Clash, while the lyricism of the verse recalls, for me, Walt Whitman.
I don't know if there are grounds for faith. Is my vocation relevant? Does it make a difference?
The world. The way it is. Is this a way to help relieve suffering?
How can you be so sure?
You seem to me to be a sensitive and generous man.
Do you think human beings are innately bad?
We are told not to judge. But to forgive. Not to look into our neighbor's eye to find the bad, but to find the good.
Now this is difficult. I admit.
But having a good friend is not always easy.
He needs help. Our help. Yours especially.

The best parts of himself come to the surface when he's helping someone learn. I've seen this. Let yourself be taught. Show your appreciation for his guidance. In this way, you know, perhaps. Well. There's hope for everyone. Even. Even Henry.

Let us pray. Lord, grant that peace be within reach for our friend, Mary. May the pain and confusion she endured on earth be fought through in the after life, so that she may enter the Kingdom of Heaven and live in the light of God. Amen.
I, Henry, take you, Fay to be my wife.
And do promise before God and these witnesses...
To be your loving and faithful husband.
For as long as we both shall live.
Bless, O Lord, this ring, that he who gives it and she who wears it may abide in your peace and continue in your favor until their life's end.
Whom God has joined, let no man separate.
Well, that could be better. But it is a hundred thousand dollars up front. Guaranteed money. You could use that.
No. Try to get him up to a hundred and fifty thousand.
Oh God, really I don't know.
Thanks, sure. I gotta go, thanks.
Hey, Fool, it's about your friend -- what's his name. Your brother-in-

The controversial and reclusive American poet Simon Grim has been awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature. The Swedish Academy, who will confer the award late next week, praised Mr Grim for works of great and difficult striving, for the rendering of the desperate, the ugly and the mundane in a language packed with our shared human frailties...
Stir things up so as to stay in the newspapers. That's his racket.
Poet, my ass! I could puke all over a piece a loose leaf and be more profound than he is!
I would have said Dickinson, maybe even Eliot, and so on. But I agree with the punk roots...
My name is Edna Rodriguez and I write the human interest column for the Queens County Examiner and I was just wondering if I could have a word with Simon Grim?

Simon, the Parents' Association at the local high school are calling your poem pornography. The teachers are defending the students' right to exercise their critical tastes and sensibilities. The county agrees with the Church and considers the poem emblematic of modern society's moral disintegration. How do you feel about these controversial reactions to your poem?
Mrs Grim, what was Simon like as a child?
Are you here to fix the plumbing?

I'm sorry to disturb you, gentlemen, but... Angus, there's a particularly wound-up young garbage man out here who seems to have written a poem. A long poem. And I recall how, at last month's meeting, you stressed the need for us to be on the look-out for more marginalized verse from unestablished quarters of the American scene.
Because he's a very important man and, well, you're not.

Sorry to disturb you again, gentlemen, but... Angus, I'd like to call security for this one. Though, before I do, I just wanted to ask just how marginal the as yet undiscovered voice of American poetry should be?
He's been denounced by his local Board of Education.
He used to be the janitor here.
Promise me you'll be on that plane at seven, Simon.
The book, as we know it, Angus, will be a thing of the past within the next few years. Novels, articles, newspapers will all be downloaded on to our personal computers anyway.
In every home in America the PC will be where the TV used to be.
An unprecedented transformation of American social life...
Oh, I read about him in the paper. Hangs out in a delicatessen somewhere and writes pornography.
So you're telling me to get out of the publishing business?
Well, OK. Make an appointment, Laura. Sometime next month.
So, anyway, how is the digital revolution going to help me sell books?
I don't think people are going to prefer reading books on television, Steve.
Hello, and why do you think I should take valuable time out of my busy schedule to read...
I'm sure you wouldn't and I appreciate you being so straightforward.
I assume you can take straightforward criticism?
Hold my calls for the next half hour.
He doesn't drink coffee. Steve, do you drink coffee?

This is really quite unbelievably bad, my friend. I mean, I'm all for experimentation and I've made a career out of a healthy disregard for convention, but... Look, this is profoundly irrelevant material. This is only my opinion. But it's an opinion I value highly. Goodnight, Laura. Call Norton Press. We're still on for tomorrow.

I've been wrong before as a publisher. But I refuse to admit I've ever been wrong as a reader. You have talent, I admit. You have an innate sense of the musicality of language. A good ear, maybe. But you do nothing significant with it. And this twisted reasoning that poses as... conviction or insight, it's... well, it's embarrassing.
Why did you bring this thing to me, anyway?
Yes, well, of course, I do. But I'm not crazy, am I? Who is this person? Do I know him?
Because I think your writing will be tremendously successful.
Other people's responses. I don't live in a vacuum, you know. Two months ago I didn't have the proof of your poem's appeal. Now I do.
Consider my offer carefully. Get some professional advice. I'll call you tomorrow.
And you want me to consider publishing it?
Simon, this book, it's... It's really quite bad.

Look, Simon, you don't require my admiration. You require my experience as a publisher. And that experience leads me to believe your poem will make more money than any book of poetry ever published. In history. Virtually make you a household name within two years. You'll never have to work on a garbage truck again, I assure you. Or do anything else for that matter. Whereas this 'Confession' by Henry Fool...
The most I can say for this is...
No! He encouraged all that was expressive in you to become manifest. He inspired you to act. He influenced your perception.
I will not publish Henry Fool's 'Confession'.
No. But we've got to re-invent the publishing business for the electronic age.
Angus, look, we have a number of charts here...
And it'll be a direct connection to all forms of media.
We'll all become better informed, more literate, increasingly productive, and... Well, and, like I said, we have a number of charts...

It all started right here in Queens, Jim, at World of Donuts about one year ago today, when local garbage man, Simon Grim, put pencil to paper and began to compose what many have come to regard as vicious, antisocial and pornographic poetry -- 112 lines of unrhymed free meter verse which would one day serve to spark the flames of controversy across the nation and -- indeed -- the world.

This is outrageous! Measures must be taken. Have we debased our culture to such an extent that a garbage man with a head full of sick ideas is legitimately referred to as a poet, and where the filth he spews can be accessed by any child old enough to turn on a computer? Is this what we have come to? Not the transmission of our highest ideals, but a cynical, atheistic delirium!

Poetry of this kind, and this poem in particular, is, I think, a worthy form of desperation; a digression on the extremes of human experience; of solitude, of community. It is perhaps alarming, even upsetting to some -- myself included -- but it must be allowed to exist.

Meanwhile, in Rome today, the Pope issued a message of hope for believers in their fight against what he termed the godless and lost. He did not mention Simon Grim by name, but offered a prayer for the young whom he described as sadly in need of faith and not the illusion of conviction offered by rock music, drugs and contemporary poetry.
Henry, what did I tell you about bringing the kid in here!
How you doin', sweetie? You wanna Coke?
Mom, can I be a mailman when I grow up?
That's what my dad always says.
'You want some?'  Henry looks away, uncomfortable. She slides her gaze over to him, their eyes meet, and she pins him to the spot.
People say you were once in jail for having sex with a girl my age.
I'll suck your cock if you kill him for me.
It is true your husband served seven years in prison for statutory rape.
Were you aware at all of the victim's relationship with his daughter?
The girl, the daughter, Pearl. She had been having sexual relations with her father.
Pearl claims she offered your husband sexual favors if he would kill her father.
I'm just repeating what she said, Mrs Fool. The victim's wife, Vicky, claims your husband broke into the house and forcefully entered her bedroom.
Fay, I know this isn't easy. But we need your help here. The girl claims she asked your husband to kill her father in exchange for, well, I guess the promise of sexual relations with her.
There ain't no one here by that name.
This is post marked five years ago.
It's an honor to meet you, Mr Grim. Really. I mean, God. Congratulations on the Nobel Prize.
I know all your work by heart. It changed my life.
You'll have to hurry, sir. They're holding the plane for you on the runway.
Mr Grim, please, the plane is waiting! We have to hurry!
This way, Mr Grim! This way!
